title: developer.uber.com/404 and developer.uber.com/docs/404 are susceptible to iframes
vulnerability_information:
#Issue
You can iframe the error pages for https://developer.uber.com/404 and https://developer.uber.com/docs/404

#Proof of concept
An example can be found here http://codepen.io/JacobReynolds/pen/VaMbde?editors=1010

#Impact
There is not a large security impact from a cursory glance at the 404 pages.  The docs page has a ReadMe.io login that is accessible in the iframe, but without some pretty clever trickery it would be hard to keylog a user's login info from there.

You are able to redirect in the iframe from /docs/404 to /404 but that is as much movement as you can get within the domains.

#Possible Fixes
Adding the X-Frame-Options:SAMEORIGIN header to the response for both of these pages would be the solution.
vulnerability_information_html:
Issue

You can iframe the error pages for https://developer.uber.com/404 and https://developer.uber.com/docs/404

Proof of concept

An example can be found here http://codepen.io/JacobReynolds/pen/VaMbde?editors=1010

Impact

There is not a large security impact from a cursory glance at the 404 pages. The docs page has a ReadMe.io login that is accessible in the iframe, but without some pretty clever trickery it would be hard to keylog a user's login info from there.

You are able to redirect in the iframe from /docs/404 to /404 but that is as much movement as you can get within the domains.

Possible Fixes

Adding the X-Frame-Options:SAMEORIGIN header to the response for both of these pages would be the solution.

activities.message:
Thank you for your report.

As you mentioned, I'm not sure I see a way for this to be exploited.  Generally, clickjacking is used to get a user to click on something in the frame that they didn't intend to click on, (and indeed usually cannot see), but without seeing the Uber login, how would an attacker get their victim to enter their credentials?  And if the attacker DID make this form visible to a user, it would still be clear to the user they weren't on uber.com from the URL bar.  And in any case, the attacker could simply make a copy of this form and place it on their site - no reason to clickjack at all.  Can you clarify the attack you have in mind?  Note that without an attack scenario this issue will likely not be eligible for a bounty via our HackerOne program.

Thanks, and good luck with your future bug hunting.

activities.message:
There appears to be no attack vector for this currently, but in my opinion it's best to seal up the frame options before one becomes apparent.  No bounty is fine, I just wanted to let you know what I found.  

Thanks for the quick response,
Jake

activities.message:
@jreynolds -- Thanks for letting us know about this; we do appreciate it.  However, as this issue doesn't appear exploitable at this time, we're going to close this report.  Please feel free to reply here or to open a new issue referencing this one if you are able to exploit this in the future.  

Thanks, and good luck with your future bug hunting.
